rev.comment: mv dictionary reference for 'to google' to a more appropriate location in the article. Add reference.
rev.diff:
Line 16: Line 16:
'''Google Inc.''' ({{nasdaq|GOOG}} and {{lse|GGEA}}) is an [[United States|American]] [[Multinational corporation|multinational]] [[software]] [[corporation]], first [[Incorporation|incorporated]] as a [[Private company|privately held corporation]] in September, 1998, that specializes in search engine, information retrieval technology and online advertising. With a market capitalization of [[United States dollar|US$]]118.32 billion as of June [[2006]], Google is the largest internet search company in the world, almost twice as large as rival [[Yahoo!]]<ref>Khan, Kim; Blaine, Charley. "[http://moneycentral.msn.com/content/CNBCTV/Articles/Dispatches/P136522.asp Google stock tops $400, worth $117.6 billion]." ''[[MSN|MSN Money]].'' [[June 9]], [[2006]].</ref> The company employs approximately 6,800 employees and is based in [[Mountain View, California]].<ref>"[http://www.google.com/press/pressrel/revenues_q106.html Google Announces First Quarter 2006 Results]." (Press Release) ''[[Google]].'' [[April 20]], [[2006]]. Retrieved on [[July 6]], [[2006]].</ref> [[Eric E. Schmidt|Eric Schmidt]], formerly [[chief executive officer]] of [[Novell]], was named Google's CEO when co-founder [[Lawrence E. Page|Larry Page]] stepped down.
'''Google Inc.''' ({{nasdaq|GOOG}} and {{lse|GGEA}}) is an [[United States|American]] [[Multinational corporation|multinational]] [[software]] [[corporation]], first [[Incorporation|incorporated]] as a [[Private company|privately held corporation]] in September, 1998, that specializes in search engine, information retrieval technology and online advertising. With a market capitalization of [[United States dollar|US$]]118.32 billion as of June [[2006]], Google is the largest internet search company in the world, almost twice as large as rival [[Yahoo!]]<ref>Khan, Kim; Blaine, Charley. "[http://moneycentral.msn.com/content/CNBCTV/Articles/Dispatches/P136522.asp Google stock tops $400, worth $117.6 billion]." ''[[MSN|MSN Money]].'' [[June 9]], [[2006]].</ref> The company employs approximately 6,800 employees and is based in [[Mountain View, California]].<ref>"[http://www.google.com/press/pressrel/revenues_q106.html Google Announces First Quarter 2006 Results]." (Press Release) ''[[Google]].'' [[April 20]], [[2006]]. Retrieved on [[July 6]], [[2006]].</ref> [[Eric E. Schmidt|Eric Schmidt]], formerly [[chief executive officer]] of [[Novell]], was named Google's CEO when co-founder [[Lawrence E. Page|Larry Page]] stepped down.
â
The name "Google" originated from a misspelling of "[[googol]]," <ref>Koller, David. "[http://graphics.stanford.edu/~dk/google_name_origin.html Origin of the name, "Google."] ''[[Stanford University]].'' January, [[2004]].</ref> which refers to 10<sup>100</sup> (a 1 followed by one-hundred zeros). Google has become well known for its corporate culture and innovative, clean products, and has a major impact on online culture. The verb "[[Google (verb)|to google]]" has come to mean "to perform a Web search", usually with the [[Google search|Google]] [[search engine]].
+
The name "Google" originated from a misspelling of "[[googol]],"<ref>Koller, David. "[http://graphics.stanford.edu/~dk/google_name_origin.html Origin of the name, "Google."] ''[[Stanford University]].'' January, [[2004]].</ref> which refers to 10<sup>100</sup> (a 1 followed by one-hundred zeros). Google has since become well known for its corporate culture and innovative, clean products, and has a major impact on online culture. The verb, "[[Google (verb)|to google]]," was officially added to the [[dictionary]] on [[July 7]], [[2006]], as a transitive verb meaning, "to use the Google search engine to obtain information . . . on the World Wide Web."<ref>Harris, Scott D. "[http://www.mercurynews.com/mld/mercurynews/business/14985574.htm Dictionary adds verb: to google]." ''[[San Jose Mercury News]].'' [[July 7]], [[2006]]. Retrieved on [[July 7]], [[2006]].</ref>
Google's services are run on several [[server farm]]s, which, in [[2004]], consisted of over 30 clusters of up to 2,000 PCs per cluster. Each cluster contains one [[petabyte]] of data with sustained transfer rates of 2 [[Gigabit per second|Gbps]]. Combined, over four billion web pages, averaging 10 Kb each, have been fully indexed.<ref name="servers">Loney, Matt. "[http://www.zdnet.co.uk/insight/hardware/0,39020433,39175560,00.htm The magic that makes Google tick]." ''[[ZDNet|ZDNet UK]].'' [[December 1]], [[2004]].</ref>
Google's services are run on several [[server farm]]s, which, in [[2004]], consisted of over 30 clusters of up to 2,000 PCs per cluster. Each cluster contains one [[petabyte]] of data with sustained transfer rates of 2 [[Gigabit per second|Gbps]]. Combined, over four billion web pages, averaging 10 Kb each, have been fully indexed.<ref name="servers">Loney, Matt. "[http://www.zdnet.co.uk/insight/hardware/0,39020433,39175560,00.htm The magic that makes Google tick]." ''[[ZDNet|ZDNet UK]].'' [[December 1]], [[2004]].</ref>
Line 79: Line 79:
As Google grows, many analysts are finding that the company is becoming more "corporate." In 2005, articles in [[The New York Times]] and other sources began suggesting that Google had lost its anti-corporate, Don't Be Evil philosophy.<ref>Rivlin, Gary. "[http://www.nytimes.com/2005/08/24/technology/24valley.html Relax, Bill Gates; It's Google's Turn as the Villain]." ''[[New York Times]].'' [[August 24]], [[2005]].</ref><ref>Gibson, Owen; Wray, Richard. "[http://www.smh.com.au/news/technology/search-giant-may-outgrow-its-fans/2005/08/25/1124562975596.html3001.asp Search giant may outgrow its fans]." ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]].'' [[August 25]], [[2005]].</ref>
As Google grows, many analysts are finding that the company is becoming more "corporate." In 2005, articles in [[The New York Times]] and other sources began suggesting that Google had lost its anti-corporate, Don't Be Evil philosophy.<ref>Rivlin, Gary. "[http://www.nytimes.com/2005/08/24/technology/24valley.html Relax, Bill Gates; It's Google's Turn as the Villain]." ''[[New York Times]].'' [[August 24]], [[2005]].</ref><ref>Gibson, Owen; Wray, Richard. "[http://www.smh.com.au/news/technology/search-giant-may-outgrow-its-fans/2005/08/25/1124562975596.html3001.asp Search giant may outgrow its fans]." ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]].'' [[August 25]], [[2005]].</ref>
â   â
As of July 7, 2006 Google became a verb, according to the [http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/google Merriem Webster Dictionary]
